Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: PSCOVAR Process
Screen.Label: PSCOVAR - Compute Covariances for PSLINV and Generate AVA Synthetics
NUM_COLUMNS=
FIRSTLINE=
NILSTRING=
TIME_COLUMN=
DENSITY_COLUMN=
PWAVE_COLUMN=
SWAVE_COLUMN=
TIME_UNITS=
PWAVE_TYPE=
SWAVE_TYPE=
WAVELET_TYPE=
PEAK_FREQ=
FREQ_LOW_NONE
FREQ_LOW_FULL
FREQ_HIGH_FULL
FREQ_HIGH_NONE
COV_WIN_TOP=
COV_WIN_BOT=
ANGLE_FIRST=
ANGLE_INC=
NUM_ANGLES=
OPT_VSVP_OUT=
LEN_SMTH_VSVP=
NUMTR=

Help.Tip: Choose PATHNAME using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
pscovar - SELECT_PATHNAME
Choose PATHNAME using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Name of input file containing well log data.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PATHNAME
Name of input file containing well log data.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = valid file name.
 
 This must be an ASCII file containing four or more columns of numbers.
 The number of columns on the file must be NUM_COLUMNS.

Help.Tip: Status of PATHNAME.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PATHNAME_INFO
Status of PATHNAME.

Help.Tip: Number of columns in the file.
Help.Text:
pscovar - NUM_COLUMNS
Number of columns in the file.
 
 Default = 4
 Allowed = integer >= 4.
 
 NUM_COLUMNS is the total number of columns in your file, which must be
 specified to allow reading the file correctly. Your file must have at least
 four columns, containing  Traveltime, Density, P-wave velocity or slowness,
 and S-wave velocity or slowness. It may have additional columns (e.g., other
 well logs), but these will be ignored by PSCOVAR.

Help.Tip: Row on file to start reading.
Help.Text:
pscovar - FIRSTLINE
Row on file to start reading.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = integer >= 1
 
 This parameter allows skipping header information, as may be present in an
 LAS or similar format file, and you may also set FIRSTLINE to start reading
 deeper in order to ignore bad values at the top of your logs.
 
 Note: PSCOVAR reads from line FIRSTLINE to the end of the file. If there are
 bad values at the bottom of your logs that you want PSCOVAR to ignore, remove
 them by editing your file before running PSCOVAR.

Help.Tip: Symbol for nil value on file.
Help.Text:
pscovar - NILSTRING
Symbol for nil value on file.
 
 Default = -999.2500
 Allowed = any character string containing no blank characters.
 
 WARNING: This is a CHARACTER STRING, not a number, so it must match the nil
 string in your file EXACTLY (e.g., -999.2500 isn't the same as -999.25).

Help.Tip: Column number containing (two-way) Traveltime values in file.
Help.Text:
pscovar - TIME_COLUMN
Column number containing (two-way) Traveltime values in file.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 - NUM_COLUMNS

Help.Tip: Column number containing Density values in file.
Help.Text:
pscovar - DENSITY_COLUMN
Column number containing Density values in file.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = 1 - NUM_COLUMNS

Help.Tip: Column number in file containing P-Wave slowness or velocity.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PWAVE_COLUMN
Column number in file containing P-Wave slowness or velocity.
 
 Default = 3
 Allowed = 1 - NUM_COLUMNS

Help.Tip: Column number in file containing S-Wave slowness or velocity.
Help.Text:
pscovar - SWAVE_COLUMN
Column number in file containing S-Wave slowness or velocity.
 
 Default = 4
 Allowed = 1 - NUM_COLUMNS

Help.Tip: Units of times in TIME_COLUMN on file.
Help.Text:
pscovar - TIME_UNITS
Units of times in TIME_COLUMN on file.
 
 Default = MILLISECONDS
 Allowed = MILLISECONDS or SECONDS

Help.Tip: Whether P-Wave values in file are Slowness or Velocity.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PWAVE_TYPE
Whether P-Wave values in file are Slowness or Velocity.
 
 Default = SLOWNESS
 Allowed = SLOWNESS or VELOCITY
 
 P-Wave and S-Wave values may be either velocities in meters or feet per
 second, or slownesses in MICROseconds per meter or foot. It is acceptable
 for P-Wave values to be slowness while S-Wave values are velocity (or vice
 versa) as long as both are in meters or both in feet.

Help.Tip: Whether S-Wave values in file are Slowness or Velocity.
Help.Text:
pscovar - SWAVE_TYPE
Whether S-Wave values in file are Slowness or Velocity.
 
 Default = SLOWNESS
 Allowed = SLOWNESS or VELOCITY
 
 P-Wave and S-Wave values may be either velocities in meters or feet per
 second, or slownesses in MICROseconds per meter or foot. It is acceptable
 for P-Wave values to be slowness while S-Wave values are velocity (or vice
 versa) as long as both are in meters or both in feet.

Help.Tip: Whether to include a Bandpass or Ricker or No wavelet.
Help.Text:
pscovar - WAVELET_TYPE
Whether to include a Bandpass or Ricker or No wavelet.
 
 Default = BANDPASS
 Allowed = BANDPASS, RICKER or NONE
 
 Your selected wavelet will be applied to reflectivities before computing
 covariances and will also appear in the output synthetic traces.

Help.Tip: Peak frequency of wavelet if WAVELET_TYPE = RICKER.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PEAK_FREQ
Peak frequency of wavelet if WAVELET_TYPE = RICKER.
 
 Default = 45.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Used only if WAVELET_TYPE = RICKER.

Help.Tip: Frequency where low frequency taper passes nothing.
Help.Text:
pscovar - FREQ_LOW_NONE
Frequency where low frequency taper passes nothing.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Nyquist >= real >= 0.0
 
 Used only if WAVELET_TYPE = BANDPASS.

Help.Tip: Frequency where low frequency taper passes full amplitude.
Help.Text:
pscovar - FREQ_LOW_FULL
Frequency where low frequency taper passes full amplitude.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Nyquist >= real >= FREQ_LOW_NONE
 
 Used only if WAVELET_TYPE = BANDPASS.

Help.Tip: Frequency where high frequency taper passes full amplitude.
Help.Text:
pscovar - FREQ_HIGH_FULL
Frequency where high frequency taper passes full amplitude.
 
 Default = Nyquist
 Allowed = Nyquist >= real >= FREQ_LOW_FULL
 
 Used only if WAVELET_TYPE = BANDPASS.

Help.Tip: Frequency where high frequency taper passes nothing.
Help.Text:
pscovar - FREQ_HIGH_NONE
Frequency where high frequency taper passes nothing.
 
 Default = Nyquist
 Allowed = Nyquist >= real >= FREQ_HIGH_FULL
 
 Used only if WAVELET_TYPE = BANDPASS.

Help.Tip: Top of Time Window (in seconds) for computing Covariance.
Help.Text:
pscovar - COV_WIN_TOP
Top of Time Window (in seconds) for computing Covariance.
 
 Default = start_trace
 Allowed = real between start_trace and end_trace
 
 The window defined by COV_WIN_TOP and COV_WIN_BOT is used for calculating
 covariance but has no effect on the output synthetic traces.

Help.Tip: Bottom of Time Window (in seconds) for computing Covariance.
Help.Text:
pscovar - COV_WIN_BOT
Bottom of Time Window (in seconds) for computing Covariance.
 
 Default = end_trace
 Allowed = real between COV_WIN_TOP and end_trace
 
 The window defined by COV_WIN_TOP and COV_WIN_BOT is used for calculating
 covariance but has no effect on the output synthetic traces.

Help.Tip: Angle (in degrees) for first synthetic trace to generate.
Help.Text:
pscovar - ANGLE_FIRST
Angle (in degrees) for first synthetic trace to generate.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Angle increment (in degrees) for generated synthetic traces.
Help.Text:
pscovar - ANGLE_INC
Angle increment (in degrees) for generated synthetic traces.
 
 Default = 5.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Number of angles for generating synthetic traces.
Help.Text:
pscovar - NUM_ANGLES
Number of angles for generating synthetic traces.
 
 Default = 13
 Allowed = integer >= 3
 
 Output gather will contain either NUM_ANGLES traces (if OPT_VSVP_OUT = NO)
 or NUM_ANGLES + 1 traces (if OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES).

Help.Tip: Whether to output a trace containing smoothed Vs/Vp ratio.
Help.Text:
pscovar - OPT_VSVP_OUT
Whether to output a trace containing smoothed Vs/Vp ratio.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES or NO
 
 If OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES, the Vs/Vp trace will be the last trace of the output
 gather and will have a value of 999.0 in header word 6.

Help.Tip: Running average smoothing length (in seconds) for Vs/Vp trace.
Help.Text:
pscovar - LEN_SMTH_VSVP
Running average smoothing length (in seconds) for Vs/Vp trace.
 
 Default = 0.1
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 A running average smoother is applied to your output Vs/Vp trace when
 OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES, to help you pick a slowly varying Vs/Vp function for use
 in PSLINV. This parameter has no effect on output synthetic traces, which are
 computed using the original (unsmoothed) Vs/Vp. It also has no effect on the
 Covariance calculation, which doesn't make use of the Vs/Vp ratio at all.
 
 You may set LEN_SMTH_VSVP = 0.0 if you want the original (unsmoothed) Vs/Vp
 to be output.
 
 Active only when OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES.

Help.Tip: Number of traces in the output gather, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
pscovar - NUMTR
Number of traces in the output gather, shown for reference.
 
 NUMTR will be either NUM_ANGLES (if OPT_VSVP_OUT = NO) or NUM_ANGLES + 1
 (if OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES).

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
pscovar - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
pscovar - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
pscovar - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
pscovar - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
pscovar - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
pscovar - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
pscovar - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
pscovar - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : PSCOVAR          (PSLINV Covariance Analysis)
 Category   : inversion
 Written    : 2004-06-24   by: Bob Baumel
 Revised    : 2007-01-03   by: D. Glover
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Well log Covariances for PSLINV and AVA Synthetics
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 PSCOVAR computes well log covariances to be used for constraining inversions
 in process PSLINV. Input to this process consists of an ASCII file, which may
 be in LAS or other columnar ASCII format, containing well logs (or even a
 sparse synthetic model) including Density and P-wave & S-wave velocities or
 slownesses. Covariances computed by PSCOVAR are displayed in the report file.
 In addition, PSCOVAR outputs synthetic traces (in the angle domain) which may
 be used for testing, and optionally also outputs a Vs/Vp trace which may be
 used for picking a depth-dependent Vs/Vp function to use in PSLINV.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 PSCOVAR is a loop-starting process, as it supplies traces to the job after
 reading an ASCII file containing well log data. Thus, PSCOVAR will normally
 be the first active process of a CPS job following JOB_DATA. In JOB_DATA
 parameters, be sure that the seismic trace length is long enough to cover
 the range of traveltimes represented by your log data, and that the seismic
 sample interval (DT) is fine enough for seismic data
 
 The ASCII file input to PSCOVAR must include at least four columns of
 numbers, containing the quantities:
    Traveltime (two-way) in seconds or milliseconds,
    Density,
    P-wave slowness or velocity,
    S-wave slowness or velocity.
 These columns may appear in any order, and the file may include additional
 columns (e.g., other well logs) which PSCOVAR will ignore.
 
 The FIRSTLINE parameter lets you start reading at any desired line in the
 file, so you can ignore header information (as present in LAS or similar
 format files) and you can also ignore bad values at the top of your logs.
 PSCOVAR reads from line FIRSTLINE to the end of the file. If there are bad
 values at the bottom of your logs that you want PSCOVAR to ignore, you
 should remove them by editing your file prior to running PSCOVAR.
 
 Setting the NILSTRING parameter can be tricky, as it needs to match the nil
 values in your file exactly as ASCII strings, not just numerically. For
 example, -999.25 and -999.2500 are not the same string. Regardless of your
 NILSTRING setting, PSCOVAR assumes that traveltimes are always non-negative,
 while Densities, P-wave and S-wave values are always positive; therefore,
 any values in these columns that fail to satisfy these conditions are
 interpreted as nils.
 
 A traveltime column must be present so PSCOVAR can place log values at the
 correct seismic trace times. Traveltimes need not be sampled uniformly (e.g.,
 the logs might still be sampled uniformly in depth), and may be sampled more
 finely than the seismic time samples. When reading your file, PSCOVAR
 resamples logs to the seismic sample rate by binning log values into the
 intervals between successive seismic trace samples and averaging all values
 that fall into the same bin. (We place bins BETWEEN the seismic time samples,
 instead of centering them on the seismic time samples, so we can calculate
 reflectivities more accurately AT the seismic time samples.)
 
 P-wave and S-wave values in the file may be either velocities or slownesses
 but must be in CONSISTENT UNITS. If both are velocities (or both slownesses),
 they should be in the SAME units. If one is a velocity and the other a
 slowness, their units must match (e.g., velocity in meters per second and
 slowness in microseconds per meter). Actually, even if the P-wave and S-wave
 units AREN'T consistent, you'll still get the right covariances, but your
 output synthetic traces and Vs/Vp trace will be wrong.
 
 The Vs/Vp trace is calculated using only the depth levels where the P-wave
 and S-wave logs are both present (although the Density log need not also be
 present). The Vp and Vs logs, after resampling and decimation to just these
 levels, are linearly interpolated/extrapolated to fill the trace; then, the
 Vs/Vp ratio is calculated.
 
 Reflectivities (for both the covariance calculation and synthetic traces)
 are calculated only in intervals where all three of the logs (Density, P-wave
 and S-wave) are present. More precisely, reflectivities are calculated only
 where there are pairs of adjacent levels (after binning as explained above)
 where all three of these logs are present at both levels.
 
 (Warning: If the log sampling is so coarse that pairs of adjacent seismic
 bins are never both populated, PSCOVAR will not calculate any reflections.)
 
 If you wish to build the ASCII file for a synthetic model with coarsely
 spaced interfaces that produce sharp reflections, then build each interface
 by entering a PAIR of rows separated by one seismic sample interval (DT) to
 produce the rock property contrasts at that interface. In particular, place
 these rows 0.5*DT above and 0.5*DT below the time where you want the
 reflection to appear. For example, if you wish to place reflections at
 1.500 and 1.700 seconds, and the sample interval in your job is 0.002 s,
 enter rows describing rock properties at traveltimes 1.499, 1.501, 1.699 and
 1.701 seconds.
 
 Covariances computed by PSCOVAR appear in the report file and include the
 following five numbers which may be used to constrain inversions in PSLINV:
    CC_RVS_RVP   = Correlation coefficient between RVS and RVP.
    CC_RDEN_RVP  = Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVP.
    CC_RDEN_RVS  = Correlation coefficient between RDEN and RVS.
    SDR_RVS_RVP  = Ratio of Std Dev of RVS to Std Dev of RVP.
    SDR_RDEN_RVP = Ratio of Std Dev of RDEN to Std Dev of RVP.
 These numbers represent correlations between  P, S and Density REFLECTIVITIES
 (RVP, RVS and RDEN) which depend on the depth distribution of P-wave, S-wave
 and Density values. They cannot be computed simply by examining crossplots of
 the original P-wave, S-wave and Density logs.
 
 Although the correlations computed by PSCOVAR cannot be derived from
 crossplots of original rock properties, it is nevertheless very useful to
 examine such crossplots. For example, they may reveal that you've been given
 a MANUFACTURED log! Sometimes, even though all three logs (P-wave, S-wave and
 Density) were recorded, one of them (typically the S-wave log) has been
 replaced with a synthetic log (e.g., calculated from P-wave and other logs)
 which may behave better for some analyses. However, to compute meaningful
 correlations for use in PSLINV, you should use genuine recorded logs!
 
 PSCOVAR allows specifying a Bandpass or Ricker wavelet which will be applied
 to reflectivities before computing their covariances and will also appear in
 the output synthetic traces. The covariances will be most valid for use in
 PSLINV if they've been computed using a wavelet with the same frequency
 content as the seismic data you intend to invert with PSLINV. The wavelets
 applied by PSCOVAR are always zero phase. But, theoretically, covariances of
 reflectivities convolved with a wavelet depend only on the amplitude spectrum
 of the wavelet, so there isn't any advantage to allowing wavelets with more
 general phase spectrum.
 
 The COV_WIN_TOP and COV_WIN_BOT parameters let you specify a time window for
 computing the covariances (These parameters have no effect on the output
 synthetic traces). Remember that PSCOVAR computes reflectivities only in the
 time range where all three of the logs: Density, P-wave and S-wave are
 present in your input file. So, even if you accept the defaults for
 COV_WIN_TOP and COV_WIN_BOT (to use entire trace), the computed covariance
 will depend only on that range, although it may include effects of wavelet
 sidelobes above and below that interval if you've applied a wavelet with long
 tails. You might use COV_WIN_TOP and COV_WIN_BOT to suppress that sidelobe
 effect or to compute covariances from only a subset of the interval where
 Density, P-wave and S-wave logs are present.
 
 The output Synthetic traces are computed using Aki & Richards approximation
 (the same approximation used for inversion in PSLINV). They are output in the
 angle domain, with header word 6 containing angle in degrees. All angle
 traces include the same wavelet; thus, these traces do not include wavelet
 stretch. (Real data processed to the angle domain would normally include
 wavelet stretch, which can be removed using process WSF.)
 
 If OPT_VSVP_OUT = YES, the final trace of the output gather will contain the
 Vs/Vp ratio. You may view this trace in Cbyt and use it for picking a depth
 dependent Vs/Vp ratio for use in PSLINV. The Vs/Vp trace has the value 999.0
 in header word 6. (This big number in header word 6 ensures that if you do
 an inversion test by running the output gather into PSLINV, and you haven't
 removed the Vs/Vp trace, PSLINV will ignore this Vs/Vp trace.)
 
 The LEN_SMTH_VSVP parameter applies a running average smoother to the output
 Vs/Vp trace, but has no effect on the covariance calculation, and also has
 no effect on the synthetic angle traces, which are computed using a detailed
 Vs/Vp sampled at the seismic sample rate.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                             REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
  6. 2007-01-03  D. Glover  Added NULLIFY statements for Intel compiler.
  5. 2006-04-20  Baumel     Add check to ignore log values with nonphysical
                            Vs/Vp ratios when calculating reflectivities.
  4. 2006-04-11  Baumel     Several small changes to match synthetics produced
                            by HSYN, which can now accept input from the same
                            kind of log files that PSCOVAR reads: To position
                            reflectors more accurately, bin log values into
                            intervals BETWEEN consecutive seismic time samples
                            (previously, they were rounded to NEAREST seismic
                            time sample). Compute reflection amplitudes only
                            for pairs of adjacent bins where all three logs
                            (Density, Vp and Vs) are present at both levels.
  3. 2006-01-10  B. Menger  Removed Unused Variables.
  2. 2005-01-17  Baumel     Compute Vs/Vp at all time levels where P-wave and
                            S-wave logs are both present, even if Density
                            isn't present.
  1. 2004-06-24  Baumel     Initial version.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
